direction.raw_text: Servants are laying a table for dinner Gas lamps and the coal fire struggle to illuminate the lofty room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Davies the Welsh cook, bangs the dinner gong and shouts across the darkening garden outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children! Franky! Horace! Dinner! Darwins attractive wife Emma adjusts the lamps and the boys run in, Franky aged 10 Lenny aged 8 Horace aged 6.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama mama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. What is it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Horace says he's six feet tall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you all washed your hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said I have to be or I can't join the army.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First things first. An officer must always tuck his shirt in. Their elder sisters Betty and Etty take their places at table
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys made a camp with a camp- fire
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh! Sneak!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's the campfire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the summer house but Brodie put it out. Parslow enters with the turreen
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank-you Parslow. Where is Mr Darwin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was killing pigeons Ma'am
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will everybody sit down please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they are pulling in their chairs, Darwin enters, drying his hands on his trousers. He's aged ten years since we last saw him and has lost his former air of gaiety. He sits, with a distracted nod to the family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soup du jour, sir The children smile at Parslow's air of earnest formality but the atmosphere even among the younger kids is sombre and subdued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you Parslow He butters some bread and starts eating. Emma clears her throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. The children bow their heads. The bread stick in darwins mouth. Emma says grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord God who watches over all that we do. Bless this family and the food we eat. In Jesus name. Amen. Everyone repeats the "Amen" except Darwin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear Mr Hooker is coming tomorrow. The children prick up their ears at this. They like Hooker
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't stay long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he say what it was about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think this is not the time to discuss it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe the time to discuss it was before you invited him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sent a telegram. I'm sorry if it inconveniences you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma purses her lips and turns her attention back to the children
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eat your soup now. Darwin takes a couple of spoonfuls, pauses, as a wave of nausea sweeps over him, then pushes away the dish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Mr Davies it was delicious, but my stomach is not quite right yet. (To Emma) Excuse me. He gets up and leaves. As soon as he has gone, the children natural talkativeness reasserts itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we take Mr Hooker to the Chalk pits. Why can't he stay. Can we pick blackberries?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think he is just here to work 17   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A branch taps gently against the window pain, like an insistent guest demanding to be admitted. The coal fire burns low in the grate - wind in the chimney rattling the damper Firelight flickers on a collection of finches in a glass case, on a bird skeleton, on a fossil, and on numerous specimen bottles containing the fleshy parts of barnacles preserved in spirit-of-wine. Darwin sits immobile in his chair, regarding a locked, black lacquered steel trunk, on the floor under his work table. A voice speaks behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't you going to open it? He turns and sees her sitting on the day bed - the same little bright eyed girl from the daguerrotype studio. She's the same age as she was then and wearing the same checkered dress - though Darwin himself has aged ten years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe best if I just burn the whole lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (horrified) No papa - You can't. I'm in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be absurd. Of course you're not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The story of me when I was small. You showed me the pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The natural History of babies" ...Remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I remember. He continues to stare at the shiny black box, his hand fluttering lightly - a nervous tic. Music seeps in - a soothing Chopin Nocturne and.... 18   INT. DOWN HOUSE DRAWING ROOM.   THE PAST. NIGHT               18 Darwin aged 40 - bright-eyed and inquisitive leans over to examine something, offering it his finger tip while making little tut tut tut noises. In the cot is a one-month old baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie. Annie. Annie. The piano music continuing over, as her fist closes round the end of his finger, then tries to pull it towards her mouth. He pulls it away from her and she frowns. He offers it again and the tug of war becomes a game. Baby Annie laughs. Darwin writes something in his notebook. Then tucks his pencil behind his ear and tries out various facial expressions - scowling, smiling - to gauge the baby's response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma turns on the piano-stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (affectionately) What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just playing. She comes over and, leaning against him, reads from his notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Six weeks: Gurgles. Holds tight to my finger. Tries to suck. Smiles at my smile" The baby lets out a long yodel of pleasure
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should add that she is musical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you do not plan to treat all our children as little animacules to be included in your experiments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you mean there will be more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I assumed that's what you wanted. Of course, if the idea doesn't appeal then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appeal? Dearest cousin. I am making plans for an army! He takes Emma in his arms. She gives a little squeak - caught off balance then laughing as he waltzes her around the room, singing. 19   EXT. WOODS AND MEADOW. THE PAST. DAY                        19 An army of children - the Darwin family - run across the screen from left to right. The little kids first, scampering through the hay meadow off into the trees. Household servants follow, carrying blankets, hampers and parasols. The red haired Scottish nursemaid Brodie, shouts ahead to the little ones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Careful! Not too far ahead now. The children ignore her so she pick up her skirts and races after them. The Adults follow in their wake - Charles and Emma Darwin plus two younger men aged about 30 - Joe Hooker and the Rev Innes 20   EXT. RIVER BANK. THE PAST. DAY                               20 They have set up their picnic on a river bank. Emma is reading. Joseph Hooker is teaching the boys to fish. He has spectacles and long wispy side-whiskers: a battered panama on his head and his trousers rolled up to his knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give it time to take a bite. The fishing float moves a little
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's Nibbling. Nibbling. Oh Bother. No-one move. He's dropped his spectacles in the shallows. George (aged 5) feels a jerk on the line. He squeals and drops the rod. The fish takes off upriver. Will goes after the dropped rod. On shore, Annie runs up with a collecting box to show her father
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got one. She opens the box to show him a little black beetle. The local parson, Innes, inclines his head to inspect it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I feed it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A leaf I should think. What plant did you find him on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the mud under that log. Innes looks to Darwin for advice
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Or a piece of bark maybe. Darwin peers at the insect
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cycrus caraboides. You can see from the mandibles he's a hunter. He feeds on slugs and snails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Annie runs off, calling to the other children
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Etty! Willy! Find me some slugs. He's hungry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I said I knew something of insects.....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh tush.... I studied Theology for a year but yet I know exceedingly little of the bible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then once I am properly installed at Down I shall take pleasure in instructing you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should look forward to that immensely. Emma, knowing her husband's ambivalence towards religion, casts him a slightly arch, amused look. Innes notices this, though he pretends not to. Hooker returns from the river, looking slightly damp, with the rod which he has managed to retrieve
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone's a bit wet. Sorry, but the fish are surely biting. More worms, boys, more worms. George is looking under stones
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try over there, Georgey, we've used all these ones up. They move off, joining Annie and the other in their hunt for crawling things. The air above them is heavy and sparkling with pollen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OCEAN. NIGHT                                            21 A sailing ship sails past, trailing phosphorescence it its wake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the Beagle, quite, often we would drop a flask in the ocean and find it teeming with living particles which glowed in the night 22   INT. SHIP'S CABIN. NIGHT                                     22 The figure in silhouette of young Darwin inspects a flask of sea water, glowing in the darkness. He takes a few drops on a watch glass and places them on the illuminated stage of his microscope. Under the microscope, against a black background, millions of tiny swimming animals. 23   EXT. BY THE RIVER BANK. THE PAST. DAY                        23 Cut to the air above the picnickers - alive with glittering particles - against the dark trees behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....so much beauty for so little purpose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surely not without purpose. They were helping to light the ship's way were they not. Darwin smiles at the idea, turns to Innes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you familiar with the works of Thomas Malthus, Mr Innes?.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He married his first cousin didn't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So did Charles.... So did I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I was not at all suggesting.... Emma waves it away. Just teasing
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He made the point that if every trout, say, has a hundred offspring And so on and so on through the generations. Then the planet would be knee deep in trout in just a few decades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course most of the eggs are destroyed and eaten so the numbers remain stable. That is the beauty of God's plan. Emma gives Darwin a "So there" look and hands Innes a sandwich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheese and cucumber
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank-you Somewhere in the woods, Annie has found a treasure trove of worms and slugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over here ....there are millions!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't strike you as an exceedingly wasteful plan - these myriad lives created only to be immediately extinguished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a gentle warning) Charles....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (confidently) They are providing food for others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think they are happy about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy? Close up on a writing worm. Hooker is instructing George how to put a worm on a hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through his bottom and up though his mouth - perfect
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....To be doing Gods will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Innes) Please ignore him. After two glasses of claret he tends to becomes mischievous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I'm serious. If thousands are destroyed that a few may live their lives, is not the general sum total of happiness not in some kind of massive deficit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well far be it from me to speculate on the mind of God, far less the happiness of an earthworm ha ha ha. But it seems to me that nature is at peace...and most of her denizens are content.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Darwin) You don't agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it is a battlefield. A constant and shifting struggle for survival between everything and everything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really do think men have a problem with natural beauty. They cannot ever just accept it for what it is. (Calls off) Children! Sandwiches! (Then) Tell me of your wife Mr Innes. Darwin lies back on the rug and turns his head away from the sun. The base of a tangled hedgerow is just a few feet away. Looking into its tangled depths he sees something gleaming white - the skull of a sheep with briars growing through the eye sockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BASE OF THE HEDGEROW. TIME-LAPSE. NIGHT                  24 The sheep's skull is half-decomposed. In fast forward we see maggots pecking the remnants of flesh from the bone, birds feeding on the maggots. A bird becomes trapped among the briars. It flaps madly upsetting a nest. Eggs and blind featherless hatchlings fall down through the dark web of branches where they are devoured by voles and rats, then slugs, then worms All the times tendrils and vines are growing, the skull - bleached white - now encased in a cage of thick spiny branches, fizzing with insect life, where ants and ground beetles feast on the carcasses of slugs and.... 25   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. DAWN                      25 Darwin wakes in sudden terror. Dawn light illuminates the wallpaper in front of him - a William Morris design of interweaving vines. Emma, is asleep in her night-cap at his side. Darwin lies for a while in the semi darkness, until his hand, fluttering on the coverlet, becomes still at last. 26   INT. SCULLERY. THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is he doing now, exactly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cutting the grass with nail scissors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Such a shame he never had a proper job. At least your Mr Thackeray had his books to write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOWN HOUSE. THE PAST. DAY                                27 Children thunder up and down the stairs between Brodie who is doing a final check on grooming and Emma who is marshalling them in the hall. 28   INT. HALLWAY. THE PAST. DAY                                   28 EMMA Chop chop Georgie. Socks! And you have not buttoned your trousers. Baby Lenny starts crying and she goes to comfort him 29   INT. GIRLS' BEDROOM. THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you never think of getting married Miss Brodie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once. But he went to Australia and I missed my chance. Willy passes the door, his hair in need of brushing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Master William. Hairbrush. William comes in. Brodie brushes the back of his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow. Ow!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well what do you expect. It is a birds nest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa says God doesn't care if we are neat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (brushing) Your father is a very wize man but has a small understanding of religion. No-one can read what goes down in Gods great book of accounts. ....Fingernails. Willy presents them for checking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can go. 30   INT. HALLWAY. THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Davies, Will you ask Jenny to wear a bonnet. I would not like people to think her fast. George aged 5 tugs at her skirt
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I bring my mouse for a blessing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What mouse? George (5) pulls it out from his pocket. Its dead, muddy and bloody
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elsie caught it in the barn. We need to pray for his soul
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mice don't have souls. Leave it on the window sill. Everyone come now or we shall be late. 31   EXT. LANEWAY. DOWN HOUSE. THE PAST. DAY                       31 Pealing of church bells Mist rises from the ploughed fields and hangs among the ancient oaks. A little procession heads down the lane. The Darwins - Charles and Emma - plus their servants and children (older now, for we have flipped into the present), all in their Sunday best. The trees are bare. Their breath condenses as they walk. 32   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE. THE PRESENT. DAY                         32 The ancient flint church stands in the centre of Downe (sic) village, opposite the George and Dragon pub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A massive and venerable Yew tree casts its shade over a number of gravestones one of them inscribed "to Mary Darwin born Sept 1842 died Oct 1842." Beyond the church fence, villagers greet each other before heading inside. The great majority of the village have turned out, from Squire Lubbock through the tradesmen and domestic servants from the village to the clodhoppers (farm labourers) in their colored smocks. Rev Innes is welcoming his large flock at the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reverend Innes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Ma'am. Welcome. Welcome Then his eye moves on to Charles Darwin and his smile falters, his expression turning slightly cold. Darwin tips his hat rather stiffly and walks away, through the throng of parishioners, leaving his family to file into the church without him. 33   EXT. WOODLAND. PRESENT. DAY                                  33 Darwin walks across the meadow and into the woods. A flock of crows take flight from the rookery in the bare trees overhead. 34   INT. DOVECOTE. PRESENT. DAY                                  34 In darkness, a furious struggle, squawking and frantically beating wings. Darwin seizes on a dove and backs out of the dovecote, the silhouette of his upper torso taking shape in the square hole in the floor. He climbs down the ladder, passes the captive bird down to Parslow, then climbs back up and pushes him upper body into the dovecot again, in search of the next victim. 35   EXT. THE GARDEN. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY                35 The dovecote is a substantial affair on four pillars with a ladder in the centre. Outside the dovecote, the boys are racing around playing at soldiers. (Franky 10, Lenny 8, Horace 6)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parslow has a number of the birds in cages
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ring the two milky pouters. We'll sacrifice the tumblers and skeletonize them. Then... He looks up as a coach appears in the lane. The boys immediately break off from their game and run after it, shouting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Mr Hooker. It's Mr Hooker! Darwin tries to wipe the bird shit off his hands and succeeds only in getting it on his sleeve. His breathing quickens. He seems at a loss. Parslow is awaiting further instructions
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then... what Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just. ...to the shed with them. I shall clean myself up. He hurries off. 36   EXT. THE FRONT GATE. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - We're the Light Brigade Horace is a Russian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good choice Horace. I shall be Lord Raglan and watch the slaughter from a safe distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Will you give us a piggy-back? - Lenny cut his foot on a nail. There was lots of blood! Emma emerges from the front door. She smiles, pleased to see Hooker despite her misgivings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then her smile falters as another man emerges from the coach behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma. Forgive the short notice. You know Thomas Huxley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only by reputation
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Darwin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He insisted on coming and I could not refuse him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell papa his visitors are here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knows already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He went that way. Emma smiles brightly, covering for her embarrassment at her husband's increasingly erratic behavior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway. Come in please. Come in. Hooker heads towards the house, the boy still clustered around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, Is it true when you were in the Himalayas you were imprisoned by the king of Sikkim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he thought you were a spy for stealing his rhododendrons?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's approximately true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....and he wouldn't let you leave unless you agreed to marry his fattest daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (Conspiratorial) ....but you are never to tell my wife that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children leave Mr Hooker alone now. I'm sure he has more important things to discuss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really, but I think Mr Huxley does.... Huxley has seen Darwin, washing his hands by the "skeletonizing shed". Huxley hangs back to introduce himself as Hooker steers Emma off into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have my heart set on a cup of tea and one of Mrs Davies' scones. Emma looks anxiously after Huxley but allows herself to be gently side-lined. 37   INT. KITCHEN. THE PRESENT. DAY .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do that ma'am. Please. Let me do it. 38   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. THE SAND WALK. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Light and noise. Crash of gleaming copperware, clattering of water in the pipes as the servants prepare Sunday breakfast The cook, Mrs Davies looks out through a steamed up window to see the angular figure of Charles Darwin, bent almost double inspecting a tiny segment of lawn. Brodie joins Mrs Davies at the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brodie is arranging hair and tying ribbons for Annie (9) Etty (6) and Betty (3)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The children come racing and swinging and clattering down the stairs. Emma, holding the baby in one arm, steers a tricycle out of the way, clearing a path to the door
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The coach pulls up and Hooker alights - ten years older than when we saw him catching fish, but still with the same hallmark side whiskers and wire-rimmed spectacles, the same springy step and ready grin. Already he is being mobbed by the younger boys - Lenny, Franky, and Horace - who clearly adore him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emma is by the kitchen window, rearranging tea things on a tray. The sky outside is dark and lowering. Through the window she can see Darwin heading off down the sand walk - head bowed, walking stick in hand - deep in conversation with Huxley. She drops a tea-cup which smashes on the stone floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Sand-walk is a gravel walking path between the garden and the fields, flanked by mature oaks and ancient willows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're reforming the Linnean. The committee will comprise myself, Lyell, Huxley...yourself of course if you are willing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin grunts noncommittally. The Crunch crunch of their feet is punctuated by the regular stomp of his metal-shod walking stick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We intend to reclaim science as a profession - wrest it away from the country parsons and beetle- collectors. Your book will be our rallying point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know it is not yet any fit state to publish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have read your detailed abstract. The argument is complete and utterly compelling. All that is lacking is the detail and we know you have that in abundance. Your barnacle work has established you as the pre- eminent authority on marine life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On one small mollusc!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In which the whole story of creation can be read. Do not pretend to me that was not your intention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honestly....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "family tree" of barnacles stretching back 300 million years to the time it was a free swimming prawn!.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are many gaps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course with gaps! But that is the very point. If we but had the complete fossil record we could trace all life back to one speck of protoplasm. The branching of forms in ever more complex succession...until.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes yes, but one cannot infer too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darwin. Either you are being disingenuous or you do not fully understand you own accomplishment. You have killed God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Huxley
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....and good riddance to the bearded malicious old bugger!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupts) Please I must beg of you....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I must beg of you sir. Joseph Hooker we know is too nice a chap to do it. You are a fine and brilliant man who hates to give offence - an admirable quality - wish I had it myself. But what do we believe? What do we know to be true. Will you light the way or leave us all to flounder in the mire for another decade. He stops and lowers himself onto a bench, teeth clenched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A touch of indigestion. It will pass. Its clearly worse than that, but Huxley, refusing to be distracted, blithely ignores it and sits down beside him til the worst of it passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is time to write your book Mr Darwin. Write it brilliantly as we all know you can. Strike hard and fast with a blow that is utterly conclusive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in pain) Sir, you are talking like a revolutionary and really...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a revolution. And not before time. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Goodbye to the lot of em - damned bishops and Archbishops with their threats of eternal punishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you'd replace Gods Laws with what.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The laws of logic. The laws of nature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Knowing, as we do, that most capital crimes are her everyday practises: Theft, rape, murder, adultery, infanticide.... Huxley waves it away
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We live in a society bound together by the church. An improbable sort of barque I grant you but at least it floats. You suggest we change all that at a stroke. You wish me to rebuild, plank by plank, the very vessel we are sailing in. 39   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Hooker. He turns. He has already said his good-byes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg you, please don't push him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No-one can push Charles. You know how fixed he is. Bit of a barnacle himself ... his own words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if you prize him from his rock he will die. I know you all mean well but....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Impatiently) All aboard! Hooker gets aboard. Huxley leans out of a window and waves cheerily to the whey-faced Darwin
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll meet again, Mr Darwin 40   INT. THE LANEWAY. DAY                                         40 The coach pulls away. Looking back though the rear window Hooker sees Emma with the boys clustered around her skirts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did she say to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That it was killing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mighty slow death considering the time he's spent. We'll be dead and buried ourselves if he prevaricates much longer. Huxley takes off his spectacles and polishes them, embarrassed by Huxley's directness, inspecting his own conscience in the bevelled glass. 41   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. NIGHT                                    41 In the darkened study, with his specimens and books all around him, Darwin kneels by the box. Steeling himself, he unlocks the padlock and opens the lid and takes out the papers and notebooks which are stored there. The bulk of it is a single manuscript, accumulated over many years, divided into 14 chapters with pages of notes interleaved. The Chapters are headed. Variation under domestication, variation under nature, Struggle for Existence, Natural Selection.... A noise behind him almost makes him jump out of his skin. Its Annie, ten years old in her checked dress, as she will always be in his imagination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you scared?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like you said. You're in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its only a book, silly. He sits there regarding the open box, paralysed by indecision. Annie tenderly smooths his hair, rearranging his collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing, Annie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm making you beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to work. Though the soft touch of her little hands is almost too real for him to bear and he closes his eyes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breath in, papa. Breathe out. Now Tell me a story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no time....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About Jenny. Please? The sound of a wave breaking. Wind stirs Darwin's hair He opens his eyes and he is .... 42   EXT. ENGLISH BEACHSIDE. THE PAST DAY                          42 Sitting with Annie ten years ago on an English pebble beach. She has collected a pile of shells and is arranging them in "families". The dialogue is continuous
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you always ask for Jenny? Its so sad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I like it. It makes me cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks up from her shells and smiles winningly. Darwin looks out to sea, at the bright crashing line of surf, and begins the familiar, much-told tale:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once apon a time there was a family of Orang-u-tangs living in the jungles of darkest Borneo 43   EXT. JUNGLES OF BORNEO. DAY                                  43 Our POV moves between dark tropical trees to find a group of Orangutans flopping around grooming each other. As with the land of the Fuegan savages, there is something slightly artificial about these jungles, as though the trees really belong in Kew gardens, and the naked jungle warriors, whom we now see stalking through them, are on loan from the museum of mankind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their eldest daughter was the most loving, caring and trusting Orang of all. We follow a young nimble female, swinging through the trees, revelling in her own gymnastic ability, until she stops - hearing something: the sound of human speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But these qualities in themselves cannot guarantee an ape's survival. Sometimes, quite the reverse. Native hunters are creeping through the undergrowth A warning screech from one of the Orang-u-tangs posted as lookouts. Most of the apes flee up into the canopy. Jenny stays where she is, fascinated, just a moment longer than is prudent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When she realized her danger it was too late. As she turns to flee a weighted net is thrown on top of her. The hunters pounce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They put her in a bag and carried her off....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: " much to her loving parent's sorrow."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly. The family screech and hoot, anguished, as the hunters head back off through the trees. 44   EXT. MARKET-PLACE. DAY                                        44 Exotic coins and bank-notes pass from hand to hand: from the tribal chief to the sultan, in his overlarge turban, from the sultan to the trader in his solar topee and stained white suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hunters sold her the to the Sultan who promptly sold her to a visiting Englishman who packed her aboard a sailing ship and brought her to London zoo. Jenny is taken out of a bamboo cage and put into a metal cage. 45   INT. CARGO SHIP. DAY                                          45 The cage is lowered by a crane. Jenny looks out from her swaying prison at spinning grey skies and brick warehouses. 46   INT. CAGE. LONDON ZOO. DAY                                    46 Now she sits disconsolately in a corner of her permanent enclosure. She has been dressed, ridiculously and poignantly in a smock and a bonnet. A group of onlookers are trying to get a reaction out of her. Eventually they give up and move on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In London she had many admirers - of whom your father was but one. Darwin moves forwards from the shadows, where he has been observing and taking notes. As the other humans move away be attempts to start a conversation with Jenny in her own language, much in the way he communicated with baby Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hoo hoo hoo hoo. Jenny regards him sceptically then looks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Coach to London has pulled up outside the front gate. Huxley is aboard. Darwin is talking with the coachman Hooker comes down the path in his black coat, carrying his Gladstone bag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: !! She startles and looks at him aggressively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hm? He reaches in his pocket. This gets her interest. She comes closer, expecting food. Darwin takers out a sprig of verbena - a strongly scented herb. He holds in front of his nose and inhales, making contented expressions of pleasure. Jenny watches. Darwin holds the verbena towards Jenny. Cautiously she extends a hand through the bars. Their fingers touch in space, like God Giving life to Adam. For Darwin its a breakthrough - a moment of connection. Jenny eats the verbena and spits it out, shrieking angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, sorry, wait - I've got something else here for you He reaches in his pocket. She cocks her head, alert. With the air of a conjurer, he pulls out: A child's hand mirror, flashing as it catches the sun through the skylights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pleasurable surprise) Ahhhh!! He shows Jenny her own reflection and, then hands the mirror through the bars. Jenny takes the mirror, bites it, discovers it is inedible, and smashes it on the ground. Charles makes a sad, whining sound
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hew Hew Hew...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pouting) Hmph. Meaning: "OK then, I'm sorry." It's such a complex human reaction - grudging contrition - that Charles laughs aloud with pleasure. Jenny laughs. Charles takes out a mouth organ and plays a snatch of Chopin. Jenny covers her ears and chatters. "Not listening not listening!" Charles, insulted, stops playing. Jenny laughs waves a hand as if to say: "Play, if it amuses you. I'm must kidding." 47   EXT. THE BEACH. THE PAST. DAY                                 47 The salt wind. The dazzling light. The slow pulse of the surf. Darwin has paused in his narrative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on what.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bit where she gets sick and dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Why do you want to hear that bit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just like it. It makes me cry. Darwin smiles, his own eyes filling with tears. Then a door opens, softly, in the sky. 48   INT. THE STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT                            48 It opens wider to reveal Emma's elegant profile, framed against the gaslight of the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her POV: the black box is unlocked and open, its contents strewn around the floor at darwins feet. Darwin is sitting on the floor of the study holding in his had a magazine, published by the Society for the useful Distribution of Knowledge, with a picture of Jenny on the cover
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you coming to bed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Presently. He doesn't move. She comes in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did Huxley want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thinks I should write it and be done with it. He feels it is a question of moral courage ...or the lack of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did not tell him about your health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His theory is that I am making myself ill by holding back. That I should lance the boil. Plunge in and hang the consequences.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank the Lord he is not a surgeon. Darwin takes a breath and plunges in himself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've concluded he is right. Bite the gag. Speed is everything. It will all be over in a matter of months. Emma is horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is not mere months that concern me Charles. Nor even years or decades... Its said quietly but with genuine anguish. To Emma it is as though her life partner has announced he's contemplating suicide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really care   so little for your immortal soul   - for the knowledge that you   and I may never be together,   in all of eternity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly) You know that what concerns you concerns me also. What do think has held me in limbo all these years. Emma has. They both know it. She turns abruptly from the door and hurries away. 49   INT. BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dearest Emma. You know This is not a decision made lightly.... 50   INT. DARWINS STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAWN                        50 In the dawn light, Darwin is writing a letter to his wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .... It has been a very slow and gradual process, like the raising of continents. 51   EXT. GARDEN. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What else can I say to you, except that it seems the process is now complete. A tear tracks down the curve of Emma's cheek as she folds the letter, puts it in her pocket and return to the business of dead-heading flowers. In voice over we hear singing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All   things bright and beautiful, all   creatures great and small. All   things wize and wonderful, The   lord God made them all. 52   EXT. DOWN VILLAGE CHURCH . THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Each little flower that opens, Each little bird that sings, He made their glowing colors, He made their tiny wings. 53   INT. DOWNE VILLAGE CHURCH. THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All things bright and beautiful all creatures great and small. All things wize and wonderful the Lord God made them all. The organ, played by Mrs Innes,   wheezes to a pause. Innes himself mounts the pulpit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us pray. Everyone bows their heads in prayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord God we know the world is governed by Thy plan. Darwin is immediately not listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks along the row of his children, standing dutifully in a line between Charles and Emma. George, aged 5, is studying the woodlice which are nesting between the pages of his hymnal
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extending even to the merest creatures thou hast made, such that even a sparrow falls not to the ground without thy will. Darwin, stands watching the play of light from the stained glass window on his shoes. Then raises his head
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Teach us that all misfortune. All sickness and death, all the trials and miseries of which we daily complain are intended for our good, being not the vagaries of an uncaring universe but the corrections of a wize and affectionate parent Innes looks up sternly and sees the Darwin's head raised among the sea of down-turned heads. Their eyes meet briefly in a sort of challenge, and in that moment, Darwin somehow knows with absolutely certainty that religious faith has left him. With a whispered word to the beadle standing next to him to take the collection Darwin slips out from the pew and heads off up the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me He's intending to be quiet and subtle but the creaking boards under his feet loudly announce his departure. Innes raises his voice above the fusillade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn with me now to the book of Job, Chapter Two verse twelve The congregation, not daring to raise their heads, watch Darwin's sturdy walking shoes departing down the aisle. 54   EXT. THE CHURCH. THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A summers day. He feels like a weight has been lifted. The church beadle comes out behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you all right, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never better. Thank-you. He heads off up the gravel path 55   INT WOODLANDS. THE PRESENT. DAY                               55 The faint and Distant sound of church singing filters through the misty woods. The black wet trunks of trees catch the sunlight. Frosty dew highlights Mistletoe and holly and dead bracken and the sudden red flash of a robin. Darwin cuts a strange dark angular figure, walking along the narrow track a single step at a time. He pauses breathing, and listens. His quick eye catches the robin seizing a worm. Further on. A pheasant breaks cover. A hare stands upright in a clearing then bounds away. Darwin looks down and takes another step, placing his feet carefully, silently so as not to disturb the wildlife. Cut to a different pair of much newer shoes in exactly the same spot. 56   INT. WOODLANDS. THE PAST. DAY                                 56 Darwin is ten years younger, pacing in the same, measured way through summer woodland. There's a noise behind him and he turns, finger to his lips for silence. Annie turns away from him and passes the sign down the line of children: Etty, George, Betty and Franky, in decreasing order of height.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shh
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to ANNIE) What are we looking at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The question comes back up the line
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A weasel. The children bunch up to gaze on a strange and wonderful sight. In a little sun-dappled clearing a weasel is turning loop the loops in a strange spiralling dance for the benefit of... ...a young rabbit, which sits utterly hypnotized by the performance. At first its strange and amusing, then the dance becomes more sinister. The weasel advancing by tiny increments as it tumbles in the air, finally
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! The weasel seizes the bunny rabbit by the back of the neck and shakes it savagely. The rabbit shrieks and spasms. Annie is beside herself, drumming the ground with her feet in a fever of fear and pity. The rabbit is still in its dearth throes, its neck broken, its back legs still jerking
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! No! Stop it. Daddy. Stop it. Make it stop. The rabbit is already dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie, Annie, Annie. He sinks to his knees, heedless of the mud on his Sunday best worsted, embracing her. The others are shocked and amazed by the rabbits death, but none of them distressed as Annie. They are country children and death is an everyday event
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chickens do that too when cookie kills them
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (tearful furious) Chickens are different! (To her father) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Why didn't you do something. You should have stopped it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The weasel has to eat. Its the way of the world. Annie
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its not fair. Its not fair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, its not fair at all. Patting her and stroking her as the little sobs subside. The weasel is dragging the dead rabbit back to its lair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....but still it is extraordinary, do you not think, that a weasel should learn to dance the polka. Despite herself the concept amuses Annie. Chest still heaving with sobs - she dries her eyes and smiles at him through her tears. 57   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOMS. THE PAST .NIGHT .
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Emma has been crying. She lies in bed pretending to sleep. Darwin gets into bed behind her. He wants desperately to reach out a hand to touch her, to comfort her, but he cannot do it for fear of weakening his own fragile resolve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: stands alone in the wintry garden, a white apron over her black dress, reading.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move in through the graveyard, past the ancient yew..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The church is packed for the Sunday Morning service The Darwin family stand in the front row. Emma, the servants and the rest of the family are singing lustily: Parslow - a somewhat pompous operatic tenor, Brodie and Innes both loudly Scottish (Innes out of tune), Annie by Darwins side, trilling along in a tuneful little descant. She notices her father is not singing and offers him her hymn book with the words. Darwin smiles and returns it. Its not that he doesn't know the lyrics, its just that he can't bring himself to say them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The rise and fall of Innes's voice continues in the background as Darwin walks out from the porch, emerging from shadow into sunlight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Piano music - Chopin - plays softly over as Charles and Emma do the rounds of their large brood of children, turning out lamps and kissing sleeping heads, taking a doll from one sleeping child's embrace, a sword from another. Shooing a cat and her kittens from the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night Lenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night Frankie
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night Betty. Darwin watches his wife, a sensuous figure, stooped over the sleeping child, a lock of hair falling forwards as she kisses her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night George
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night Etty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night Willy
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-night Annie She's sound asleep. Finally Charles and Emma are alone together in the blissfully silent house. Emma smiles
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear Charles
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dearest Emma He takes her hand and leads her to their bedroom. 58   EXT. THE BEACH. THE PAST. DAY                                 58 Emma lies on a rug, her head is in Darwin's lap. She is reading aloud from a new book of poems by Wordsworth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Loving she is, and tractable though wild. And innocence hath privilege in her. To dignify arch looks and laughing eyes; And feats of cunning; and the pretty round Of trespasses, affected to provoke Mock chastisement, and partnership in play" She puts the book down
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Then we were wrong. She is not unique after all. Darwin is watching Annie dancing in front of the surf , turning cartwheels - a wild dancing sprite of the sea, oblivious to the cold, shouting and singing: 59   THE BEACH. LATER                                              59 Later, Near the cliff, Darwin is "geologising" He's excited, breathless and windswept, shouting over the sound of the nearby surf as he clambers over the huge assorted boulders pointing out the geological strata to his kids who are more interested in clambering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Devonian, about 400 million years ago. Rocks like this might have fishes in them, trilobites, tree ferns, corals maybe.... He knock off a corner of rock with his geological hammer, then moves on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this a bit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No that is Cretaceous Etty. It was made a hundred millions years ago, when this cliff was a coral reef and Down village was a swamp full of great crocodiles. Tap tap tap with his hammer as the boys scramble upwards, playing at mountaineers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We might find oysters and sponges imprinted in it, or dinosaurs if we were lucky...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's a dinosaur?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Professor Owen invented them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are the giant lizards which lived on earth before there were any humans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they weren't real
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course they are, Betty. Did I never tell you of the skeletons I found in South America (to Etty) Do you remember Mr Martell?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Annie arrives, hopping nimbly over the rocks still in her wet swimsuit
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes you do. When he came to tea and showed us drawings of his Iguanodon. And George burnt his fingers roasting chestnuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should have your clothes on Annie. You are quite blue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Savages don't swear clothes. She runs to the top of a great fallen rock, spreads her arms out, and yells to the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a Fuegan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well don't fall and hurt yourself. Your mother would never forgive me. Annie gives a shout and disappears head over heels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've found one! In the rubble at the base of the rocks she has landed, unhurt and quite by accident on a perfect specimen of a fossilized trilobite. 60   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY                        60 The black box lies open with all its secrets strewn around the office. Stacks of paper - a stack for every chapter - are held down with paperweights - a fossil, a skull, a specimen bottle. Darwin squares a stack of blank paper between his hands, then reaches for his pen. 61   INT. VILLAGE SCHOOL. THE PAST . DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reverend Innes is giving the children their writing lessons, according to "Mulhauser's technique"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First positions. The children assume the position as if in some militaristic drill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second positions. Grips are adjusted, pens are dipped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Assume the distance. The children lean back fractionally, so their elbows are just back from the edge of the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .....and begin. The Children start to copy the sentence which Innes has written on the blackboard. Annie reads the sentence and hesitates: "And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested" 62   INT DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dearest Hooker. I am one week into the great project and I feel at last that it is real. Its title is "On the Origin of Species." As I write theses words why does it feel as though I am confessing to a murder... A paper stirs in the breeze and he pins it with the nearest object to hand - Annie's trilobite. His eye rests on it a moment CUT TO 63   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PAST . DAY                         63 The corrugated gray surface, greatly magnified. The Darwin of ten years ago is examining the trilobite with a watchmakers eyeglass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a small mirror above his desk, angled so as to give him a view of the path leading round from the front of the house. Innes appears briefly in it, preceded by Annie, who is trotting to keep pace with him and crying. Darwin, intent on his work, notices neither of them From downstairs he hears the door knocker then Brodie's voice, then Emma's overlapping with half-heard fragments of Innes's Scottish brogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you needed to know why I had to chastised her. Darwin remains immersed, examining each detail of the trilobite, comparing it with other specimens in books and in boxes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....It is not fair to the other nor to Annie herself that her head be filled with these ideas....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you listening, Annie? Annie sobs louder, incoherent in her grief. Darwin finally focusses on the sounds, recognizes her distress and gets up to investigate. 64   EXT .UPPER HALLWAY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall bid you good day then The front   door closes. Darwin comes downstairs
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its not nothing. (To Annie) Why are your knees bleeding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Innes had to have words with her. It is sorted now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Words are very well. I am asking what happened to her knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Innes sent me to the corner and made me kneel on rock-salt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a rush) I said there were dinosaurs and he said there wasn't dinosaurs but there were because you saw them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) Annie. Let me talk to your father. He told her to kneel til she repented...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Repented what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bleeding is due to her own stubborn-ness. It is finished now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is by no means finished. Where is my coat. Its intolerable
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles. Please. Charles ignores her, Forcing his arm into the sleeve of his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Innes is a dear friend and neighbor. I beg you at least appraise yourself the facts. She contradicted him repeatedly. The fault was Annie's Mr Innes was quite within his rights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (his arm is stuck) In his rights to torture our children for expressing the plain truth. Brodie appears and Darwin ushers Annie towards her
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Darwin massages his cramped hand then takes a blank sheet of notepaper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He reaches the top of the stairs. Annie is directly below him, slumped, still sobbing at the foot of the stairs. Emma has ushered Innes to the porch out of sight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...Please take her to           It is not the truth as he kitchen.                        sees it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well damn how he sees it. Damn the pair of them and all their works
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles listen to yourself. Listen Blocking his path as he heads for the door. Her palm flat on his lapel, soothing, reasoning with him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma please. I will not have Innes tell me what I can and cannot tell my children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is what I have told them every night at bedtime. It is the instruction my aunt and your brother and most of our family live by. It is what all of the village believe ...or try to. Charles. Must our children be revolutionaries at nine years of age. Write to him with your concerns - our concerns - about the manner of the punishment but please do not set yourself against him. Think of my feelings on this. I beg you. Finally his outrage has spent itself, neutralized by her gentle persistence and the deep affection he holds for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right of course.... I'm sorry. He embraces her. Emma is reassured, she cannot see the conflict written all over Darwins face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STUDY. DAY. (THE PRESENT)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're still angry with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can always tell by your playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not angry. I'm sad. 67   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY                         67 Darwin sits at his desk, writing and editing, his hand clamped on the pen. A voice speaks from nowhere
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still writing) And say what? She does not want to hear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then write to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (irritably) That is what I am doing Annie, I am writing all of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY                                    68 Emma, passing the open door glimpses Darwin talking angrily to himself as he writes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....and then she can read it, and we can all be free of this! Now, please, Annie no more interruptions! 69   EXT. GARDEN. DAWN                                           69 The music continues, louder. A frosty coating of dew covers the lawn. Footprints lead to a strange wooden tower in the garden. Parslow stands outside, shivering in the grey morning light. Darwin shouts from inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pull! Parslow pulls a lever. There's the sound of crashing water, a yell of pain from inside the tower. Ravens rise, calling, from the surrounding trees. 70   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY                       70 Darwin dips his pen, scores out some text from his previous draft and writes again. The music continues from downstairs, louder and more insistent than before. 71   LOUNGE ROOM. THE PRESENT. DAY                               71 Emmas hands race back and forwards along the piano keyboard. 72   INT DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT                             72 Darwin's pen scratches across the pages, making a noise like fingernails on a blackboard. The music from downstairs seeming to drive into his skull
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He speaks aloud the words he is writing, in an effort to drown out the piano music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... In time small variations become extreme... Strange detailed drawings of barnacles are strewn across his desk, seeming to change and transmute before his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Organs change their very function, the oviduct becomes a cement gland. He stops. His hand is shaking too much to write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's an oviduct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing that need concern you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what it is anyway. Darwin gets up abruptly from his desk. 73   INT. WATER TOWER. DAY                                        73 DARWIN Pull! Darwin stands naked, clutching to two hand rails for support as a great tub of freezing water tilts and pours its contents on top of him. Darwin yells 74   EXT DOVECOTE                                                 74 Birds rush out from the dovecote 75   INT. STUDY                                                   75 Darwin dips his pen and writes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....What was once a free- swimming creature now finds itself glued by its head to a rock, flailing for food with its legs...,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Revolutionary etude is continuous now - real or imagined. 76   UNDER THE SEA                                                76 Surf crashes. Underwater, among the swirling seaweed, fragile sea creatures being torn this way and that by the raging surf 77   INT. MALVERN SPA TREATMENT ROOM. DAY                         77 Annie screams and kicks her legs, overwhelmed by water in some dark place. Pull back to reveal: 78   INT. HELL.                                                   78 A vision of hell: The water is fire. The barnacles are people. The people are Annie, Emma and Darwin. 79   INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT                                          79 Darwin wakes in a panic and sits up in bed. He raises his right arm and looks down at his inky writing hand fluttering in the moonlight, like an organ with a will all of its own Emma is a sleep. There's a crucifix on the wall above her bed. On the bedside table there's a bible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...About the midst of this valley I perceived the mouth of hell to be; and it stood also hard by the wayside. Now, thought Christian, what shall I do? 80   INT. NURSERY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT                             80 The children are gathered around Emma who is reading a bed- time story to them by lamplight. Emma is in the centre of a circle of little attentive faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's aware of Darwin, standing in the darkened corridor beyond the door, drawn to the cosy little group but unable to join it. She lets him be. Continues reading
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And ever and anon the flame and smoke would come out in such abundance with sparks and hideous noises, that he was forced to put up his sword, and betake himself to another weapon, called "All Prayer"..." 81   INT. ETTY'S ROOM NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Daddy not coming to kiss us good-night
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is still a little bit ill from working ...maybe tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what you said last night. Emma turns out the light. In the darkness Etty says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think when Annie died he stopped loving us. Emma returns to her bedside
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh come now, Etty. You know that's not true. He is just a little bit ill - and a little bit busy. 82   INT. BOILER ROOM. DAY                                        82 In the bowels of Down House the house, we find Darwin wrapped in wet towels sweating in front of the wood-burning stove. As he gazes into the leaping flames, Annie appears at his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there really such a place as hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No of course not. How can there be? If he is supposed to be loving and forgiving - what on earth is the sense punishing all these millions of souls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But just suppose if there was. And all this was punishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All what? No reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you mean. All what? 83   INT THE WATER TOWER. DAY                                     83 Darwin stands, legs apart in the water tower bracing himself like a colossus against the full force of the deluge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pull! 84   EXT THE WATER TOWER. DAY                                     84 The gardener, splitting logs, watches Darwin stagger from the tower with a rug wrapped around him, and make his way back to the house. 85   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to Mr Innes. Please. You are clearly not well
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is what? A physician now
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I mean. I think he can help you. Charles remains stubbornly silent, his hand fluttering over the coverlet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am taking the children to Maer for a while, to visit their cousins. (Beat) I worry for you, Charles. Please talk to him 86   INT DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY                                       86 Fire flares in the grate as Darwin compares the skeletons of various pigeons. He starts a new Chapter: "changes under domestication" 87   INT. THE DOVECOTE. THE PRESENT. DAY                           87 Pigeons mate and coo in the dusty twilight. 88   EXT. THE DOVECOTE. THE PRESENT. DAY                           88 Parslow picks up two of them, casually wrings their necks and heads off with them to the skeletonizing shed. 89   INT. DARWINS STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY                          89 Darwin Looks out of the study window, searching for inspiration. He sees Emma and the children getting into a coach with their baggage. 90   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you be eating sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thank you. Parslow leaves. Darwin addresses the empty room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie? .....Annie. She will not come. 91   EXT. THE BEACH.    THE PAST. DAY                             91 Annie dancing in the surf. One minute she is there and the next she has vanished, lost among the churning waves. Darwin leaps top his feet shouting
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie! Raucous male laughter takes us to 92   INT. PUBLIC HOUSE. THE PAST. EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darwin! Mr Darwin! I was explaining to Mr Goodman here your interest in breeding. Mr Darwin is our foremost scholar in the village.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No I am but one of many. There is Squire Lubbock, and the reverend Innes The Thatcher waves them away as lesser talents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....he is also a noted explorer, the author of many books..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...which no-one has read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...a fellow of the Royal society and a prodigious expert on clams...oysters?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barnacles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Goodman, now, is the foremost pigeon fancier in all the southern counties. Kent champion two years running. I swear he can give you any beak or plumage in four generations. Head and tail in five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By breeding cousin with cousin. I find it the fastest way to alter the strain - provided you do not weaken it in other ways. Darwin takes a slug of whiskey 93   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY.   THE PRESENT. NIGHT                     93 He is drinking in his office. The clock strikes twelve. The page in front of him remains stubbornly blank Darwin is rising from his desk when he sees something move. In one of the bottles on his desk, a fleshy marine specimen seems to have come to life. It writhes blindly in its bottle of formalin, making a sound like a baby crying. Darwin, recoiling in horror, pushes himself back from his desk. The castors on his chair trundle back from his desk. Behind him he hears a tapping and turns to see that all the birds in his big glass display case of Galapagos finches have started to beat against the inside the crowded glass case. They flutter, frenzied, tapping with their beaks on the inside of the glass, which shatters as... One by one the bottled specimens explode, discharging their contents onto the floor. A lamp falls over. The room is filled with birds the floor awash with formalin and broken glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Study seems to tilt like the cabin of a ship in a storm and. 94   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. DAWN                     94 Darwin wakes from the nightmare asleep at his desk, the whiskey bottle a quarter empty, ink on his hands and his shirt cuffs He gets up and puts on his shoes. 95   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DRAWING ROOM. THE PRESENT. DAWN .
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The conflicted expression has hardened, the furrows in Darwin's brow etched deeper, as he dips his pen and begins the second chapter. From the floor below we can hear Emma practising a piece of music on the piano - Chopin's revolutionary etude: a rippling, brooding arpeggio running up and down the keyboard, redolent of an angry sea. Darwin's pen scratches doggedly over the paper. 66   INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the bedroom, in his nightgown, Darwin scrubs the ink stains off his fingers with a pumice stone. Emma passes behind him, preparing for bed. He glances at her in the mirror
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The older girls Etty and Betty finish their prayers and jump into bed in their night-gowns Emma comes in to take away their lamp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darwin lowers himself into bed, inky and tousled. He seems prematurely aged, crippled by the gruelling process of writing the book. As he lies there, unable to sleep lines of written text seems to appear behind his closed eyes, or in the tangled vines of the wallpaper. Emma speaks from the other side of the bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darwin sits at his desk. He has written the chapter heading and nothing else. Parslow knocks and looks in
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The George and Dragon on a Saturday night. The air loud with laughter and thick with pipe smoke. Clodhoppers crowd the snug, many of them roaring drunk, with their florid complexions, stained and broken teeth. Darwin trying, to slip in discreetly is spied by a group of locals who hail him and gather around him, wedging him into a corner with their overloud loud talk and laughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The scullery maid, lighting the fire, looks round and sees Darwin. He walks past her without a word and heads out into the garden. 96   EXT. DOWN HOUSE GARDEN. THE PRESENT. DAWN                    96 Darwin heads across the lawn, takes a key from his belt and opens the door of the skeletonizing shed. 97   INT. SKELETONIZING SHED. THE PRESENT. DAWN                   97 In the grey light he takes in the corpses of doves from the dovecote. Some have been skinned, their pelts curing on frames, their carcasses steeping in a buckets chemicals which remove the flesh from the bones. Previously he regarded this place as a sort of laboratory. Now it seems a place of horror. The door opens behind him. Its Parslow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get rid of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which ones sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of them. All of it. 98   INT. DOVECOTE. THE PRESENT. DAWN                             98 Darwin reaches into the dovecote and starts grabbing pigeons at random, dragging them out and flinging them into the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go. Go! 99    EXT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAWN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Displaced doves beat the air. Darwin climbs down the ladder, grabs and axe and attacks the wooden stanchions supporting the dovecote Parslow comes running over from the skeletonizing shed, calling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir. Mr Darwin. Darwin stands back, hair wild, eyes crazed, his sleeves covered in bird shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please rest sir. I'll have John Lewis remove it. Have some breakfast now and rest. Shall I call the doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or the water tower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pox on all of them! 100   INT. ANNIE'S ROOM. THE PAST. DAY                              100 The local doctor Henry Holland takes out various concoctions from his medical bag and arranges them on the dresser. We are in the past. Annie is in bed with a fever. Emma is pregnant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calomel then, twice daily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not give it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles....                        Mrs Darwin, it is nothing but chloride of mercury. I have prescribed it often in children as young as two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to any of mine I hope. On the Beagle I dropped some on a microscope slide and all my animacules died of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well animacules are not persons. Presumably they would die if you dose them with Madeira wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Madeira they thrived most excellently, as did Captain Fitzroy, while it lasted. Annie enjoys the joke and gives Darwin a weak smile. The doctor regards her balefully
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or if she would submit to be bled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will write to Dr Gully again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sceptical) The hydro-therapist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have always found his treatments most effective.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...no matter that they defy all sense of logic. He is packing up his bottles and his lancets
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Logic is not everything. Emma shoots him a look. Til now scientific logic has been his guiding principle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I shall bid you good day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parslow will bring your carriage. I will be down presently The doctor leaves the room. Emma is in a terrible quandary
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should take her to Malvern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it is better she is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gully can care for her properly there. She can be treated daily, as I was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles no. She is better with us. With her family. Please do not take her away from me. 101   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. THE PRESENT. DAY                       101 Parslow enters to find his master staring vacantly into space. The page in front of him is still blank. The study is in chaos. It seems as though the contents of the black box have multiplied and spread out to colonize every corner of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Post for you sir. He leaves it by Darwins elbow and backs out. After a while Darwin seems to rouse himself. He picks up the largest envelope, postmarked Malaysia, and slits it with a letter knife. The sender is a Mr Wallace. There's a covering letter and a twenty page attachment Darwin reads, and lets out a sudden loud bellow of laughter.
direction.name: direction
