direction.raw_text: Ha!! 102   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin sits in sunshine at the rear of the house, rugged up against the cold. Looking frail still, but oddly at peace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, there you are Mr Darwin. Darwin looks up blinking in the sunlight to see the stocky, dark-suited figure of Mr Innes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I join you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By odd means He makes some space on the bench. Innes hesitates, unable to read Darwin's feelings towards him. The smile is welcoming enough but there is something not altogether balanced about it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Darwin informed me you would be alone and ....perhaps a need to counsel. He sees an envelope on the ground and stoops to retrieve it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You dropped this. What a beautiful postage stamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It is from the Spice islands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do rather envy your wide circle of correspondents. In my youth I always wanted to travel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are still young. You could be a missionary and follow in Mr Livingstone's footsteps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, although I have always felt there is quite enough evil at home without looking for it abroad. (Then, casually) Mrs Darwin told me of the book you are writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not any more, thank goodness
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have finished it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has been finished for me. My correspondent In the spice islands has arrived independently at exactly the same idea, expressed in a mere twenty pages. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) There's brevity for you. I had so far covered two hundred an fifty and come to a dead end. So finally I am rid of the project. Innes is relieved to hear it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Lord moves in mysterious ways.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does indeed Mr Innes. I was reflecting only the other day on the fact that he has endowed us in his blessed generosity with not one but nine hundred species of intestinal worm each with its own unique method of infiltrating the blood supply and burrowing through the mucosa. Innes shifts uncomfortably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then again on the great love he shows for butterflies by inventing a wasp to lay eggs inside the living flesh of caterpillars
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. It is not for us to guess at His reasons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. We can leave that for Mr Wallace now. Should I advise him to stay overseas do you think? If he shows his face in Kent he may be required to kneel on rock salt. Innes rises. He's a short man, acutely aware of any threats to his dignity, and he's had enough of this mockery
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I once valued our friendship Mr Darwin. I had hoped it might be possible to restore it. Clearly in your present mood that is not going to be possible. My regards to Mrs Darwin He starts off round the corner of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin listens to his footsteps receding, then turns his face back to the sun. When he opens his eyes sees a figure standing in the lawn. It is Annie, plain as day, scowling at him angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? I am forestalled by Mr Wallace. That is the simple fact of it. What reason do you have to be angry?! She shoots him a look of hatred then turns away from him and runs off towards the meadow. Darwin, instantly remorseful, gets to his feet and hurries after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie! He reaches the centre of the lawn and stopped by a sudden intense pain in the gut which strikes him like a blow and fells him to his knees. He lies their gasping, his vision clouding as the pages of the Wallace letter slip from his grasp and are scattered to the wind. A view from high above: spiralling downwards on the Darwin garden, as household servants emerge from various quarters and hurry to his assistance. 103   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are some faint stains on the plasterwork of the bedroom ceiling. Like lichen on a rock. Like an archipelago of islands. Darwin lies, pale and weak, looking upwards from a sea of white blankets. The door opens and he turns his head. Its Emma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a visitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No. I will not be bled or lectured to. She gives him a pinched look, then Hooker pushes in behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is me. Thank God you are still with us. Word came from London you had suffered an apoplectic stroke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Simply the great relief of liberation. Did you read the Wallace abstract. Hooker bats the idea away
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a letter. You have a book
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...barely half of it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a book. What is not already on the page is most certainly inside your head and I intend to extract it, if it kills us both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have been talking to Huxley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Had I done so he would have hastened here himself armed with every instrument of torture known to her majesty's navy. (Then) Charles I have read the first Chapters. It is brilliant. You must continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot. Seriously Joseph, I am completely blocked. All my old symptoms have returned with a vengeance. The sweats the shakes the abdominal pains. The whole endeavour was cursed from the outset. Hooker takes darwins hand, presses it to stop it from trembling
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles. It was you who opened my eyes to the wonders of science. So let me open yours. You have an illness. You have had it as long as I have known you. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) It is clearly made worse in times of overwork but the nature of the work is irrelevant. This is not visited on you by God or the devil. This is a set of physical symptoms. Go to Malvern and get treated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not Malvern
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not. What is there to be scared of there. He has worked for you in the past it will work again. Then come back and finish the book. Your enemies are already toasting their good fortune but they shall not prevail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about. I have no enemies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are legion, believe me, and they are implacable. We are all of us fighting a battle against fear and superstition but we can win this battle. We must win it. You can win it for all of us. Go to malvern, then come back and finish it. 104   INT. DOWN HOUSE. THE PAST. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upstairs, Servants are packing for a journey. The vigorous Darwin of the past moves swiftly from room to room, gathering his things. Hat and gloves, books, spectacles, papers. Emma, eight months pregnant, tries to keep up with him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles, please reconsider
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma it is weeks now, months. She is getting worse, not better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I am coming with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cannot come. How can you possibly come in your condition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is not so far.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is two days by coach and train. Who will look after the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not care for the others. I care for Annie! Etty, coming apon then unexpectedly, hears this and is instantly heartbroken. EMMA is devastated by the slip but is presently too overwrought to retract it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave us please, Etty. Parslow has gathered up Annie from her room and is carrying her downstairs, pale and sickly-looking, with Brodie fussing behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make sure she is tucked in. Watch her shawl
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't need to go. At the bottom of the stairs, Darwin takes Annie from Parslow's arms
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The coach is outside. I will carry her from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama... She clasps Emma's hand. Darwin keeps heading for the door. Emma holds fast to Annies hand and follows behind
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will see Mamma when you are better. Say goodbye now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parslow holds the door open. The coach is at the Gate. Emma stops on the threshold, unable to let go her daughters hand and suddenly deeply convinced that she is making a mistake here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. I am coming with you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Emma
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait there. She hurries back inside. Darwin makes a decision and heads for the coach. 105   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY                                           105 Down the patch and through the open gate with the servants following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get aboard. Brodie
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama! The garden gate clangs shut behind them. 106   INT. DOWN HOUSE STAIRWELL/ UPPER HALLWAY. THE PAST. DAY        106 Emma looks out of the upstairs window, realizes they plan to leave without her and hurries downstairs again. 107   INT. COACH. THE PAST. DAY                                      107 Charles bundles Annie inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go. Go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The coach sets off. Emma runs to the gate calling desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles. Please God. No. Annie! 108   INT. COACH. THE PRESENT                                       108 Charles, feeble and debilitated, levers himself into the coach with Parslow assisting and slumps back in the leather upholstery. Servants gather at the gate. Some of them tearful, not expecting him to return 109   EXT. STEAM TRAIN. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A steam train comes charging past trailing plumes of black smoke, striking sparks from the track with its wheels. 110   INT. CARRIAGE. THE PRESENT. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sickly Darwin of the present sits hunched and nauseous, with Parslow sitting beside him with his suitcase on his lap. Every jolt of the train sends a spasm of pain through Darwin's guts. The people sitting opposite - a woman, a child, and a man - regard Darwin in silence. Whatever he suffers from its not good and they are worried about getting infected with it They plunge into a tunnel. The carriage fills with smoke. Parslow gets up and tries to close the window but it won't budge. A burning ember flies inside and lands on Darwin's leg. Darwin is too weak to lift a finger. Parslow slaps the ember and extinguishes it. 111   EXT. STATION. MALVERN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train wheezes to a halt. The doors open and the train disgorges its cargo of sick people, come to Malvern for treatment - a coughing child, a woman with one side of her face aflame with shingles - the halt the lame and the afflicted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HORSE AND CART. DAY                                      112 Darwin sits in the back as the attendant drives them through Malvern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him not this way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello there. Stop. Can we go by the other route
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Worcester Road is shorter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...by the low road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wishes to go by the other route.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As you will sir. He backs up the horses and turns the cart around 113   INT. GULLY'S CLINIC. DAY                                      113 Dr Gully is the chief physician at Malvern spa. His marble- tiled consulting rooms resound with the sound of rumbling pipes and dripping water. Darwin reclines on a leather couch, watching the watery play of light on the ceiling. A door opens and Dr Gully comes in, accompanied by two assistants. Gully is a small dapper man wearing an apron over his shirt and tie. His trousers are tucked into calf-length Wellington boots. He greets Darwin cheerfully, effusively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darwin, old friend. Mr Darwin. It has been too long I fear. Tut tut tut tut tut. What have we now what have we now? He clasps Darwin's hand, feeling his pulse at the wrist, then commands him to open his mouth
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: tongue... Darwin shows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ugh. Shirt up. Let me feel your liver. Darwin untucks his shirt. Gully prods at Darwin's belly. Darwin winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulse hectic, togue furred, liver tender and enlarged. Darwin's ink stained fingers speak volumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt you have been exercising your brain every hour that God gave you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was persuaded to write book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madness there are far too many of those already. Are you Sleeping?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poorly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose never taking the 50C dilution of Chelidonium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shakes his head) I had the gardener build a water tower. It no longer has any effect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not. Your gardener is not a hydrotherapist. What on earth possessed you ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feared I was dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh come come come. We shall not have that talk here. Half turning to his assistant, who is staking notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A smart spinal scrub. Cold douche daily at 7.00. Wrapping in towels and sweating by the lamp. Then, to Darwin:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No red meat, no reading, no mental agitation of any kind. We shall soon have you right old friend, we shall have you right. 114   INT. TREATMENT ROOMS. DAY                                    114 Music over: Darwin sits in a deep metal bath while one of Gully's assistants scrubs his spine with a loofah. 115   INT. DOUCHE. DAY                                             115 Darwin stands in a shaft of light, grabbing onto the hand rails as the icy flood continues to crash down on his shoulders, splintering and fracturing in the shaft of light. 116   INT. TREATMENT ROOMS. DAY                                    116 Two assistants bind him tight in damp linen sheets, til he is immobilised like a cocoon, with his legs together and his hands by his side. They pick him up and lie him down, quite rigid beside another pod like creature, similarly swaddled, with a red face and a beard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darwin is it? Darwin nods, unable to turn his head, or make any gesture with his hands. The stranger continues to talk to him nonetheless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William Carter of Southampton. I read your Beagle account many years ago. Former naval man myself. What brings you here? Myself, a Bilious fever with blood per rectum, but I have every faith in Gully. The man is a miracle worker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TREATMENT ROOM. DAY                                    117 Darwin sits with a blanket draped over his shoulders, under the merciless glare of a heat lamp. Sweat pours off him and forms puddles at his feet. 118   EXT. TERRACE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bright sunny day. Darwin, looking weak but purged, sits on the terrace, sipping a glass of foul-tasting mineral water and looking out over the stone houses, fields and valleys of Malvern. Gully sits with him, interviewing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What action do you most associate with the symptoms. Eating? Strong emotion? Strenuous Excercise?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does the exercise of memory count as an action.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Memory of what.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My eldest daughter. You remember her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Of course. You must accept there was nothing more we could do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that. I know. A long, awkward silence, neither of them wants to recapitulate the events of Annies death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You say you were writing about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. It is a scientific text. But I had reached a point, beyond which it was impossible to progress. She had been my companion throughout. Now it seemed she was ahead of me in a place I could not follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Plainly she is in heaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is what my wife believes. It is a great consolation to her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma and I have become ...divided on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it affect your marital relations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have none ...to speak of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a beat) Are you familiar with the writings of DeQuincy."There is no such thing known to the mind as forgetting."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what it means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He suggests we have thoughts which do not actually enter the realm of consciousness. Nervous fibres exist after all throughout the whole body. Is it not possible that certain primal feelings manifest in some physical way. Eczema. Boils. A fever. Might some blocked passion imitate a gall-stone? Or even manufacture one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, until someone devises a machine to read nervous impulses, or a telescope to look inside the body I suppose we can only guess at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can Mr Darwin. We can look inside you. If you find yourself open to it, there is a way of seeing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREETS OF MALVERN. NIGHT                                119 Darwin wanders the cobbled streets of Malvern, pausing occasionally to consult a hand-written address. It is starting to rain as, finally, he arrives at the address he is looking for. A substantial terraced house. Darwin descends a stone staircase to the imposing front door, and rings the bell. As he waits for an answer a woman appears, unseen in the rain streaked window above, observing him. Darwin rings again. A moment later the woman answers the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs St John?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darwin. Come in. 120   INT. MRS ST JOHN HOUSE. NIGHT                                 120 The room is large and hot, crowded with pot plants, and bric- a-brac. Various fringed lamp-shades, a dancing Shiva, a framed picture of Lourdes, and some illustrations from the Tarot. None of this inspires Darwin with confidence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just leave your coat on the table. Sit down here. Show me your palm. The husky voice and the plunging decollete troubles Darwin, who hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. I'm confused. What is it you do exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I envision what's inside your belly, dear. That's what you wanted, isn't it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Envision how? When Gully described you I fancied some scientific instrument....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Depends what you class an instrument. In more resistant cases I might use a pendulum...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He frowns. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its ten shillings for a reading by the way. In advance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. I have a ten shilling note here in my wallet. He doesn't take it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you can tell me the numbers on it we can begin. Mr St John' face hardens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a professional lady Mr Darwin. I don't do party tricks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a professional man. And I asking for no more than I ask of all my colleagues - a demonstration of competence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is you who are here to be tested, Sir, not me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I am sorry to have wasted your time. He puts his jacket back on and heads for the door. 121   INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs St John follows him. As he reaches for the doorhandle, and opens it, she says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's with you, you know that. Darwin turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your little girl. I saw her from the window standing at the top of the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How dare you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...prey on people's grief like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have done no such thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you take me for an idiot? Clearly Gully has appraised you of my history.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg to inform you he did no such thing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is chicanery of the very lowest order and I despise it utterly!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out. 122   EXT. THE HOUSE. DAY                                           122 Darwin steps outside and she slams the door on him. Darwin continues to rant at the closed door, standing in the pouring rain without his umbrella. He gets to the top of the steps, and looks around, trying to get his bearings. In a pool of lamp-light at the far end of the street a figure stands watching him. Darwin squints at her through the rain, which is falling harder now. The figure is Annie. She looks at him crossly, then heads off up a cobbled side- street. Darwin follows. 123   EXT. MALVERN. SIDE STREETS. VARIOUS. NIGHT                    123 Darwin pursues his daughter up narrow cobbled lanes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie. Annie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rain is getting heavier, turning the gutters into rivers. Water overflows the drains and culverts and rushes over the cobbles, making them slick and treacherous. Darwin hurries down darkened lanes and alleys, the sound of rushing water echoing all around, the little girl always ahead of him. A DRUNK MAN in oilskins comes barreling past him, head down, cursing the weather. A child's ball goes floating downhill in the current. Darwin loses Annie, then he sees her again, at the top of a steep flight of stone steps. Darwin, drenched chases after her. 124   EXT. WORCESTER ROAD. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the top of the steps he stops for breath and he looks around. There is no sign of Annie but he knows this street - The Worcester Road - a row of Grey Georgian houses, their backs against the hill, their sloping front gardens looking out over the rooftops of Malvern. Most of the street is in darkness but the house directly opposite has lights in the window. He knows this house also. He hesitates, then crosses the street towards it. 125   EXT. GUEST HOUSE. NIGHT                                       125 Soaked to the skin, he raps with the brass door-knocker, then waits for someone to answer. Muffled voices. Then a man answers from within.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Mrs Carey still the landlady here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The door opens on a chain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My daughter Annie ...lodged here some years ago. Can I come in? The man closes the door to release the chain, then opens it again to admit Darwin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know this is an intrusion. I wonder - could I visit the room she stayed in? The landlord doesn't know what to make of this
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait here. I'll get the missus. He leaves Darwin dripping in the hallway which he goes and consults with his wife in the lighted parlour. Darwin looks around. This place is all too familiar to him - the bevelled gold-rimmed mirror, the carved mock-Tudor coat- stand. Muffled conversation off. There are crutches and walking sticks among the umbrellas. Lavender potpourri in a brass dish. A wheel-chair in one corner, a picture of the pieta above the door. Finally, the land-lady emerges from    her parlour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which room?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fourteen. I would only be there ten minutes. I am happy to pay. She goes into an alcove and emerges with a key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up one flight and along the corridor to the right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try not to touch anything. 126   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PRESENT. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin, climbs the stairs to the Landing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GUESTHOUSE. THE PAST DAY                               127 The younger Darwin flees up the stairs. 128   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PRESENT. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The older Darwin, reaches the top of the stairs and walks along the corridor to the right. 129   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PAST DAY                               129 The younger Darwin, races along the corridor. 130   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PRESENT NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The older Darwin, hesitates, chest pounding, outside the door of number 14, then unlocks it as... 131   INT. GUESTHOUSE. THE PAST. DAY                              131 The younger Darwin bursts into room 14 and takes in the scene. The room is full if light. A maid is bundling soiled sheets. Brodie is there with a harrassed-looking Dr Gully. They turn as he enters. Annie lies on the bed between them, her breathing fast and shallow. She manages a weak smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is she any better? Does she want for anything? Gully stands up from the bed. His expression tells us hope is fading. Annie's pale sunken cheeks and caked lips confirm it. Darwin kneels by her bedside, clasps her little hand is his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling Annie. I am here now. Annie lets out a reedy whine of appreciation and strokes his lapel "making him beautiful" Brodie cannot bear it and bursts into tears. 132   INT. ROOM 14. THE PAST NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie sleeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin sits up, writing to Emma, crying as he writes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dearest Emma. I think it best for you to know how every hour passes. It's a relief for me to tell you. Whilst writing to you I can cry tranquilly. 133   INT. ROOM 14. THE PAST DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A local surgeon lays out various instruments, including a glass syringe with a long needle. Annie struggles and whimpers. Brodie comforts her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Coates the Surgeon came today to draw off Annie's water. This did not hurt her, but she struggled with surprising strength against being uncovered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There there. It will all soon be over. 134   EXT. CHURCH AT MALVERN. ENTRANCE. DAY                        134 Darwin enters through the heavy stone entrance. 135   INT. THE CHURCH AT MALVERN. DAY                              135 The relatives of the sick, stand or sit among the pews, arriving, praying, departing Darwin kneels awkwardly in front of the altar, clasps his hands together and prays:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Save her. I will believe whatever. Forever. Please save her He looks up at the image of Christ on the cross, hoping against all reason, for some sense of epiphany. It's not working. He feels nothing embarrassment at the cheapness of the gesture. 136   INT GUEST HOUSE. ROOM 14.   THE PAST .NIGHT
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin sits alone with Annie who is babbling incoherently. He can't make out anything she says
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Our dear child has taken a turn for the worse. She talked a great deal but we could seldom make out anything. Much of what she says we cannot make out from the roughness of her poor mouth. 137   INT. GUEST HOUSE. ROOM 14 NIGHT                             137 Dr Gully leaves, the surgeon arrives. The maids squeeze between the two medical men, bundling sheets
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today she vomited rather much again. Dr Coates has been to draw off more water. Brodie and the maid roll Annie on her side and cut off the tail of her shirt, then roll her on her back again, with a pillow between her two bony knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that good, my lovely
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beautifully good. I am making custards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gully thinks her in imminent danger. 138   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heavily pregnant Emma sits in the drawing room, crying and reading Darwin's latest letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We sponged her with water and vinegar, made her sweet with chloride of lime....I fear we must prepare ourselves for the worst 139   INT. ANNIE'S ROOM. GUEST HOUSE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is midnight Darwin, exhausted, keeps a lonely Vigil by Annie's bedside. Each breath seems like it will be her last. Suddenly she speaks: faintly but audibly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rabbit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rabbit taught him the polka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand my love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about Jenny. Darwin bends low to hear her more clearly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When she died
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to talk about death my love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But tell me. I like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. What the keeper told me was. When she was very sick with pneumonia, lying very still, he tried to feed her but she shook her head, looking at him as though to say: "Its nice of you but really you shouldn't bother". And as he bent down to take the spoon away she brought her arms around his neck and kissed him. And then she was dead. Annie smiles, puts her hands around her fathers neck and dies. 140   INT. TRAIN THE PAST DAY                                       140 Darwin sits, his face wet with tears, reading, through blurred vision, a letter from Emma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was in the garden looking at our poor darling's little flower bed when John Griffiths drove up with your letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DARWIN'S BEDROOM. NIGHT                                141 Emma goes to bed, utterly drained.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I went to bed I felt as if it had all happened long ago. When the blow comes it wipes out all that preceded it. 142   INT. DARWIN'S BEDROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens the curtains on a bright day. The other children are playing in the garden
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My feeling of longing for our lost treasure makes me feel painfully indifferent to the other children, but I shall get right before long. 143   INT. TRAIN CARRIAGE. THE PRESENT. DAY                       143 Darwin sits in the train, Heading home from malvern. He is looking across the carriage at his younger self, re- reading the letter and weeping uncontrollably. 144   EXT DOWN HOUSE. LOUNGE. THE PRESENT. NIGHT                  144 Torrential rain crashes down on the house, the garden, the ancient trees and the outbuildings, flooding the path and the lane beyond the gate. Darwin pays the coachman and hurries inside 145   INT. DOWN HOUSE. LOUNGE ROOM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma is playing a beautiful slow Nocturne. The rain outside drown out all other side. She doesn't notice the figure of Darwin until he appears, like a ghost, reflected in the polished wood of the piano. She turns with a start and sees him, still in his dripping coat, hair plastered over his brow
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. I startled you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take your coat off by the fire there. What time is it? Darwin stays where he is, dripping on the carpet
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need to talk. I need to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, but dry your hair. I shall call for a towel. As she moves to the bell-pull he grabs her wrist
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went back to Worcester Road. I saw Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles. No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to hear it. This must stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do! Do you think me deaf and blind. You have lived with her and spoken with her every day since she died. Parslow comes in with firewood then sees Emma yelling at darwin and hurriedly retreats, spilling logs in the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is more real to you than I am. She's dead Charles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what is wrong with you that even our poor daughter cannot be left in her grave but you would....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know she is dead. I know it. It is you who will not accept the fact, preferring to think of her in heaven. This again! The unspoken argument which has been brewing for a decade, never before expressed so bluntly. Emma heads for the door
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get away from me! She heads into the hallway, he follows her ranting
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snowy white wings and dancing with the angels. Is that your idea of honesty. Servants scramble out of sight and out of earshot
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you come back. I will not hear this! Emma picks up her skirts and hurries up the stairs. Darwin pursues her. On the landing, Betty and Horace, wide eyed and terrified are bundled into the nursery by Brodie as Charles thunders up the stair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to Emma, everything these was between us is gone. The boat is wrecked and sunk now. We have to hold to something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To what. Your ghosts? Your theories? What Charles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To the truth of what we know it. She slams the bedroom door on him and bolts it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open this door Emma. The truth, how wonderful and extraordinary our daughter was....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (through the door) I know that. I do not need you to say it. Of course I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles throws his shoulder to the door and bursts through it. Emma screams
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But free of the fantasy, free of the rest, the silly vain hope that we will be reunited in heaven and the nagging unspoken belief that I killed her! In the lower hallway all the servants hear this In the nursery, Brodie, aghast, covers the childrens ears In the bedroom, Emma has nowhere left to run
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have never said that
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say it now. Say it. And all the rest that follows. That I should have kept Annie warm that day on the beach. I should not have taken her to Malvern. I should have let you come. Tears spring to her eyes and to his. The fury has gone from both of them, leaving sadness and pity
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should have insisted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. It was me. I took her from you It was my fault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could have followed. I was her mother what was I thinking of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thought she would live. You were not to know. He moves to her, she startles, then lets him enfold her in his damp coat
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did. I did know. I knew when you left that I would never see her again. I hated you for taking her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hated myself. I knew that none of them could save her. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) All I could do was watch hopelessly and weep for her - then flee the place in terror, not even waiting to see our poor dear daughter buried. She was our treasure and I failed her. We both did. We should never have married each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The unspeakable . I am saying that you and I, in making our perfect child, endowed her with the very weakness which killed her. Emma. That is what I couldn't write. That is what forestalled me all these years. It wasn't you I was angry with, it wasn't Innes and it wasn't God. I was angry with my theory. It was the truth I was angry with. It is the truth. Weeping, she shakes her head in furious denial. He kisses her hair, her eyes, her tear-streaked cheeks... 146   INT/ EXT BEDROOM, THE PRESENT. NIGHT                         146 Rain continues to batter the house outside Inside Darwin and Emma make love, with a kind of wild desperation, their clothes strewn all over the floor, clinging to each other like castaways in a storm. 147   INT OFFICE. THE PRESENT. DAY                                 147 Darwin enters his office. The chaos that existed here previously has been tidied away into files and boxes. Darwin opens the black box, takes out the files, places them on his desk, then sits down and begins to write 148   INT. STUDY. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin sits at his desk. Writing. He is possessed of a new sense of calm and purpose, the pen gliding fluently across the page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Night turns to day and then to night again. Darwin completes the Chapter headed "variation under domestication" and begins on a fresh sheet of paper. 149   EXT. THE GARDEN. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY               149 Crocuses are pushing up through the flower beds. Tiny green buds have started to emerge from the dead black branches 150   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DOWN HOUSE. THE PRESENT. DAY           150 Still Darwin writes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me a story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm busy Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll go away again, then you'll be sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, come here, come here. She comes and sits on his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once there was a man Who, while travelling in South America, came apon a beautiful and dangerous idea. 151   INT. SOUTH AMERICAN JUNGLES. DAY                            151 Darwin is in the south American jungle, trying to coax down from the trees, some small squeaking creature - a tousled looking abandoned chick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, here. Come on, come on then The creature draws closer, eyes like gimlets in the dark foliage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I wont hurt you. He reaches into the dark recesses of the forest. Darwin grabs it and stuffs it, squawking into his collecting bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DARWIN'S STUDY NIGHT                                     152 Darwin comes in, empties the bag into a black box with perforations and closes the lid
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knew his wife wouldn't care for this creature so when he came home he locked it in a box, where it couldn't run around and do any damage. 153   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY                                      153 Darwin works at his desk. There's a plaintive cooing sound coming from the box next to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But every so often he'd open the lid and feed it, just because he couldn't bear to let it die. Finally he opens the lid and offers the creature a biscuit. It has grown a bit larger and made itself a nest. It takes the biscuit and peeps gratefully. 154   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY                                          154 Darwin goes to the box and opens it. There's nothing there but an empty nest and some broken eggshells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One day he opened the box and discovered it wasn't in there at all. It had escaped with all its babies, who were nesting all over the house making a terrible mess. 155   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DAY. VARIOUS                                 155 The Darwin's, their children and their servants run around the house finding birds everywhere. There is bird-shit on the curtains and the antimacassars, birds nesting in the sewing basket, the bread bin and the dress-up box. Every time you open a cupboard, angry birds fly out and flap angrily around the room. Mayhem. The house is in uproar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But finally they caught them all, and bundled them in a blanket and he asked his wife to dispose of them as she saw fit. 156   INT. STUDY. CONTUNUOUS                                       156 Annie listens entranced. Darwin pauses
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what did she do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know but I fancy she took them out in the garden and set them free. 157   EXT. DOWN HOUSE. GARDEN DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma and Brodie come out carrying a huge white linen bag between them. They shake it out in the garden and birds come pouring out of it. High shot, looking down on EMMA as she watches the birds wheeling round and round in the sky above. 158   INT. DARWIN'S STUDY. DAY                                     158 Darwin sits in his study window, watching a great flock of birds wheeling in the sky outside, the whole flock forming an ever-changing shape from the movement of its tiny component parts. 159   INT DARWIN'S STUDY. NIGHT                                    159 Darwin puts down his pen, waking, as if from a dream. The manuscript is finished. The music of Chopin filters up from downstairs. 160   INT. DRAWING ROOM. DAY                                       160 Emma is playing by candle-light. Darwin places the manuscript on top of the piano. She stops abruptly. The last chord resonates in the musky air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Done. I have finally got it out of the air and into these pages. Will you read it and decide what must be done with it. I confess I no longer know and I am very tired. She takes his hand and squeezes it. 161   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin undresses. 162   INT. DOWN HOUSE   DINING ROOM                               162 Emma sits at the table and begins to read. 163   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BATHROOM                                   163 Darwin gets out of the bath and towels himself dry. 164   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DINING ROOM                                164 Emma lights a candle from the one before and continues to read. 165   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles lowers himself into the bed, sleep washes over him like a wave. 166   INT. DOWN HOUSE. DINING ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still Emma reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thus, from the war of nature, from famine and death, the most exalted objects we can conceive directly follow. There is a grandeur in this view of life ...in which endless forms most beautiful and wonderful have been and are being evolved. Outside the sky is growing lighter. 167   INT. DOWN HOUSE. BEDROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles wakes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the curtains on a clear autumn day. The house is unusually quiet. 168   INT. DOWN HOUSE. TOP OF THE STAIRS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The grandfather clock on the landing strikes mid-day. Darwin goes downstairs. 169   INT. DRAWING ROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He enters the drawing room. There is no sign of Emma nor of his manuscript. He goes to the window and sees her at the bottom of the garden standing over a bonfire, burning something. 170   EXT. GARDEN. DOWN HOUSE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darwin goes outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emma? She looks up from the fire. Darwin crosses the lawn to her. She's burning leaves and dead-heads from the flower garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you read it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wrapped it and put it on the table there. There's a brown paper parcel on the garden table where they like to sit under the big Cyprus tree. Darwin picks it up, it is addressed to John Murray, Publisher, stamped and sealed with sealing wax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. True or not it must all be said. Probably most of it is true. God help us. Darwin kisses her.
direction.name: direction
